stories.text:
Hi all,

Just released a new version of taskwarrior-syncall (https://github.com/bergercookie/taskwarrior-syncall). It's a bi-directional synchronization framework, which keeps in sync your Taskwarrior tasks with a variety of other services including Google Calendar events and Notion.

In the latest version, I'm adding support for synchronization with checklists in Google Keep. I.e., every Taskwarrior task is converted and kept in sync with an item in a google keep note check list.

Demo here: https://github.com/bergercookie/taskwarrior-syncall/blob/mas...
stories.title: Show HN: GoogleKeep Taskwarrior Bi-Directional Synchronization
Statistics legend Ross Ihaka reflects on his revolutionary software

stories.text:
Over time I've developed an internal library which I think is super neat. It's a state management library for react and we use it everywhere in our codebase for some time. I asked my employer if I could open source under my GitHub to which my boss responded that it should go under the companies' GitHub and now is not the right time to do that.

It just feels so unfair to me. I guess he is probably correct legally speaking. This kind of legal flex really demoralizes me though. Am I now at risk of some legal issue by even disclosing this discussion publicly?

Have you had this issue before? What's your view?
stories.title: Ask HN: How to respond to employer denying request to open source my library?
